info.title: API Reference
info.description: Review our [API Introduction](../api-introduction) to get started.

tags.name: Organizations
tags.description:
An Organization is the highest level of hierarchy in Turnkey. It can contain many Users, Private Keys, and Policies managed by a Root Quorum. The Root Quorum consists of a set of Users with a consensus threshold. This consensus threshold must be reached by Quorum members in order for any actions to take place.

See [Root Quorum](../concepts/users/root-quorum) for more information

tags.name: Invitations
tags.description:
Invitations allow you to invite Users into your Organization via email. Alternatively, Users can be added directly without an Invitation if their ApiKey or Authenticator credentials are known ahead of time.

See [Users](./api#tag/Users) for more information

tags.name: Policies
tags.description:
Policies allow for deep customization of the security of your Organization. They can be used to grant permissions or restrict usage of Users and Private Keys. The Policy Engine analyzes all of your Policies on each request to determine whether an Activity is allowed.

See [Policy Overview](../managing-policies/overview) for more information

tags.name: Wallets
tags.description:
Wallets contain collections of deterministically generated cryptographic public / private key pairs that share a common seed. Turnkey securely holds the common seed, but only you can access it. In most cases, Wallets should be preferred over Private Keys since they can be represented by a mnemonic phrase, used across a variety of cryptographic curves, and can derive many addresses.

Derived addresses can be used to create digital signatures using the corresponding underlying private key. See [Signing](./api#tag/Signing) for more information

tags.name: Signing
tags.description: Signers allow you to create digital signatures. Signatures are used to validate the authenticity and integrity of a digital message. Turnkey makes it easy to produce signatures by allowing you to sign with an address. If Turnkey doesn't yet support an address format you need, you can generate and sign with the public key instead by using the address format `ADDRESS_FORMAT_COMPRESSED`.

tags.name: Private Keys
tags.description:
Private Keys are cryptographic public / private key pairs that can be used for cryptocurrency needs or more generalized encryption. Turnkey securely holds all private key materials for you, but only you can access them.

The Private Key ID or any derived address can be used to create digital signatures. See [Signing](./api#tag/Signing) for more information

tags.name: Private Key Tags
tags.description: Private Key Tags allow you to easily group and permission Private Keys through Policies.

tags.name: Users
tags.description: Users are responsible for any action taken within an Organization. They can have ApiKey or Auuthenticator credentials, allowing you to onboard teammates to the Organization, or create API-only Users to run as part of your infrastructure.

tags.name: User Tags
tags.description: User Key Tags allow you to easily group and permission Users through Policies.

tags.name: Authenticators
tags.description: Authenticators are WebAuthN hardware devices, such as a Macbook TouchID or Yubikey, that can be used to authenticate requests.

tags.name: API Keys
tags.description:
API Keys are used to authenticate requests

See our [CLI](https://github.com/tkhq/tkcli) for instructions on generating API Keys

tags.name: Activities
tags.description:
Activities encapsulate all the possible actions that can be taken with Turnkey. Some examples include adding a new user, creating a private key, and signing a transaction.

Activities that modify your Organization are processed asynchronously. To confirm processing is complete and retrieve the Activity results, these activities must be polled until that status has been updated to a finalized state: `COMPLETED` when the activity is successful or `FAILED` when the activity has failed

tags.name: Consensus
tags.description:
Policies can enforce consensus requirements for Activities. For example, adding a new user requires two admins to approve the request.

Activities that have been proposed, but don't yet meet the Consesnsus requirements will have the status: `REQUIRES_CONSENSUS`. Activities in this state can be approved or rejected using the unique fingerprint generated when an Activity is created.

contact.description: Email or phone number to send the OTP code to

emailCustomization.description: Optional parameters for customizing emails. If not provided, the default email will be used.

smsCustomization.description: Optional parameters for customizing SMS message. If not provided, the default sms message will be used.

userIdentifier.description: Optional client-generated user identifier to enable per-user rate limiting for SMS auth. We recommend using a hash of the client-side IP address.

sendFromEmailAddress.description: Optional custom email address from which to send the OTP email

timestampMs.description: Timestamp (in milliseconds) of the request, used to verify liveness of user requests.

organizationId.description: Unique identifier for a given Organization.

otpId.description: Unique identifier for an OTP authentication

email.description: Email of the user starting recovery

targetPublicKey.description: Client-side public key generated by the user, to which the recovery bundle will be encrypted.

expirationSeconds.description: Expiration window (in seconds) indicating how long the recovery credential is valid. If not provided, a default of 15 minutes will be used.

emailCustomization.description: Optional parameters for customizing emails. If not provided, the default email will be used.

timestampMs.description: Timestamp (in milliseconds) of the request, used to verify liveness of user requests.

organizationId.description: Unique identifier for a given Organization.

userId.description: Unique identifier for the user being recovered.

receiverUserName.description: The name of the intended Invitation recipient.

receiverUserEmail.description: The email address of the intended Invitation recipient.

receiverUserTags.description: A list of tags assigned to the Invitation recipient.

senderUserId.description: Unique identifier for the Sender of an Invitation.

organizationId.description: Unique identifier for a given Organization.

targetPublicKey.description: Client-side public key generated by the user, to which the oauth bundle (credentials) will be encrypted.

apiKeyName.description: Optional human-readable name for an API Key. If none provided, default to Oauth - <Timestamp>

expirationSeconds.description: Expiration window (in seconds) indicating how long the API key is valid. If not provided, a default of 15 minutes will be used.

providerId.description: Unique identifier for an OAuth Provider

providerName.description: Human-readable name to identify a Provider.

issuer.description: The issuer of the token, typically a URL indicating the authentication server, e.g https://accounts.google.com

audience.description: Expected audience ('aud' attribute of the signed token) which represents the app ID

subject.description: Expected subject ('sub' attribute of the signed token) which represents the user ID

providerName.description: Human-readable name to identify a Provider.

userId.description: Unique identifier for the authenticating User.

apiKeyId.description: Unique identifier for the created API key.

otpId.description: ID representing the result of an init OTP activity.

otpCode.description: 6 digit OTP code sent out to a user's contact (email or SMS)

targetPublicKey.description: Client-side public key generated by the user, to which the OTP bundle (credentials) will be encrypted.

apiKeyName.description: Optional human-readable name for an API Key. If none provided, default to OTP Auth - <Timestamp>

expirationSeconds.description: Expiration window (in seconds) indicating how long the API key is valid. If not provided, a default of 15 minutes will be used.

invalidateExisting.description: Invalidate all other previously generated OTP Auth API keys

userId.description: Unique identifier for the authenticating User.

apiKeyId.description: Unique identifier for the created API key.

limit.description: A limit of the number of object to be returned, between 1 and 100. Defaults to 10.

before.description: A pagination cursor. This is an object ID that enables you to fetch all objects before this ID.

after.description: A pagination cursor. This is an object ID that enables you to fetch all objects after this ID.

policyId.description: Unique identifier for a given Policy.

effect.description: The instruction to DENY or ALLOW a particular activity following policy selector(s).

notes.description: Human-readable notes added by a User to describe a particular policy.

consensus.description: A consensus expression that evalutes to true or false.

condition.description: A condition expression that evalutes to true or false.

publicKey.description: The public component of a cryptographic key pair used to sign messages and transactions.

privateKeyName.description: Human-readable name for a Private Key.

curve.description: Cryptographic Curve used to generate a given Private Key.

addresses.description: Derived cryptocurrency addresses for a given Private Key.

privateKeyTags.description: A list of Private Key Tag IDs.

exported.description: True when a given Private Key is exported, false otherwise.

imported.description: True when a given Private Key is imported, false otherwise.

curve.description: Cryptographic Curve used to generate a given Private Key.

addressFormats.description: Cryptocurrency-specific formats for a derived address (e.g., Ethereum).

privateKeyId.description: Unique identifier for a given Private Key.

payload.description: Raw unsigned payload to be signed.

encoding.description: Encoding of the `payload` string. Turnkey uses this information to convert `payload` into bytes with the correct decoder (e.g. hex, utf8).

hashFunction.description: Hash function to apply to payload bytes before signing. This field must be set to HASH_FUNCTION_NOT_APPLICABLE for EdDSA/ed25519 signature requests; configurable payload hashing is not supported by RFC 8032.

signWith.description: A Wallet account address, Private Key address, or Private Key identifier.
